DESCRIPTION: Addresses cybercrimes involving damage to computer systems, networks, or data, including unauthorized access, data theft, and virus introduction.
PUNISHMENT: Fine up to ₹1 crore.
FAMOUS CASES: State of Maharashtra v. Suraj V. Gajbhiye (2020); Rajeev Kumar v. M/s HCL Infosystems Ltd. (2021)

DESCRIPTION: Mandates that organizations collecting, storing, or processing sensitive personal data must protect it; failure results in liability.
PUNISHMENT: Compensation to affected individuals.
FAMOUS CASES: Google India Pvt. Ltd. v. The Directorate General of Foreign Trade (2017); Jabong v. Ranjan S. (2020)

DESCRIPTION: Establishes the Cyber Appellate Tribunal to hear appeals related to cybercrimes and digital certificates.
PUNISHMENT: No specific punishment; facilitates adjudication.
FAMOUS CASES: Shreya Singhal v. Union of India (2015); Google India Pvt. Ltd. v. Tamil Nadu (2017)

DESCRIPTION: Deals with the appointment of the Controller of Certifying Authorities (CCA) to regulate digital signatures and certificates.
PUNISHMENT: No criminal penalties; focuses on regulatory oversight.
FAMOUS CASES: Tata Consultancy Services v. The Controller of Certifying Authorities (2009); National Informatics Centre v. Controller of Certifying Authorities (2014)

DESCRIPTION: Addresses tampering with computer source code, including unauthorized modification or concealment.
PUNISHMENT: Imprisonment up to 3 years, or fine of ₹2 lakh, or both.
FAMOUS CASES: State of Maharashtra v. Bharat Bhushan (2015); ITDC v. K. R. Shankar (2020)

DESCRIPTION: Covers a wide range of cybercrimes such as hacking, data theft, and identity fraud.
PUNISHMENT: Imprisonment up to 3 years and/or fine.
FAMOUS CASES: Shivendra Yadav v. State of UP (2016); Cyber Crime Investigation Unit v. Sanjay S. (2019)

DESCRIPTION: Previously penalized sending offensive messages online; struck down in 2015 as unconstitutional.
PUNISHMENT: Initially imprisonment up to 3 years and/or fine; now repealed.
FAMOUS CASES: Shreya Singhal v. Union of India (2015); Amitabh Bachchan v. State of UP (2014)

DESCRIPTION: Criminalizes knowingly receiving stolen computer resources, data, or devices.
PUNISHMENT: Imprisonment up to 3 years, or fine of ₹1 lakh, or both.
FAMOUS CASES: Ravi Kumar v. State of Tamil Nadu (2019); Bharti Airtel v. Rajesh Kumar (2020)

DESCRIPTION: Penalizes identity theft, including unauthorized use of personal credentials for fraud.
PUNISHMENT: Imprisonment up to 3 years and/or fine of ₹1 lakh.
FAMOUS CASES: State of Gujarat v. Ajay Verma (2018); Rajeev S. v. ICICI Bank (2017)

DESCRIPTION: Penalizes cheating by personation using computer resources, including phishing and online scams.
PUNISHMENT: Imprisonment up to 3 years and/or fine of ₹1 lakh.
FAMOUS CASES: State of Maharashtra v. Vinay Kumar (2018); Ashok Kumar v. Paytm (2019)

DESCRIPTION: Addresses unauthorized capture, publication, or transmission of private images, protecting digital privacy.
PUNISHMENT: Imprisonment up to 3 years and/or fine of ₹2 lakh.
FAMOUS CASES: Ravi S. v. Delhi Police (2020); State of Rajasthan v. Pradeep K. (2021)

DESCRIPTION: Covers cyber terrorism, including hacking critical infrastructure and online terror activities.
PUNISHMENT: Life imprisonment or fine.
FAMOUS CASES: Afzal Guru v. Union of India (2013); Indian Cyber Army v. Hacking Group (2019)

DESCRIPTION: Publishing or Transmitting Obscene Material in Electronic Form
PUNISHMENT: Criminalizes publishing or transmitting obscene content via electronic form, including sexually explicit material or offensive content.
FAMOUS CASES: First offense: Up to 3 years imprisonment and/or ₹5 lakh fine; Subsequent offense: Up to 5 years imprisonment and ₹10 lakh fine.

DESCRIPTION: Publishing or Transmitting Sexually Explicit Content
PUNISHMENT: Criminalizes publishing or transmitting sexually explicit content, including pornography.
FAMOUS CASES: First offense: Up to 5 years imprisonment and/or ₹10 lakh fine; Subsequent offense: Up to 7 years imprisonment and ₹10 lakh fine.

DESCRIPTION: Publishing or Transmitting Child Pornography
PUNISHMENT: Targets the distribution, transmission, or publication of child pornography in electronic form.
FAMOUS CASES: First offense: Up to 5 years imprisonment and/or ₹10 lakh fine; Subsequent offense: Up to 7 years imprisonment and ₹10 lakh fine.

DESCRIPTION: Preservation and Retention of Information by Intermediaries
PUNISHMENT: Mandates intermediaries to preserve data related to users' activities for at least 90 days.
FAMOUS CASES: Failure to comply may result in penalties.

DESCRIPTION: Power to Add to the Contents of the Electronic Form
PUNISHMENT: Gives the Central Government the power to amend, modify, or add to electronic records or forms under the IT Act.
FAMOUS CASES: No specific punishment mentioned.

DESCRIPTION: Power to Intercept, Monitor, or Decrypt Information
PUNISHMENT: Allows the government to intercept, monitor, or decrypt information for national security or public safety.
FAMOUS CASES: No penalties prescribed; grants authorities surveillance power.

DESCRIPTION: Blocking of Websites and Content
PUNISHMENT: Grants the government power to block access to websites that threaten national security or public order.
FAMOUS CASES: Non-compliance by intermediaries can result in penalties.

DESCRIPTION: Monitoring and Collecting Traffic Data
PUNISHMENT: Allows the government to monitor and collect data traffic for cybercrime investigations and national security.
FAMOUS CASES: No penalties prescribed; focuses on data monitoring.

DESCRIPTION: Protection of Critical Infrastructure
PUNISHMENT: Protects critical information infrastructure from cyberattacks.
FAMOUS CASES: Unauthorized access can lead to severe penalties, including imprisonment.

DESCRIPTION: Misrepresentation of Electronic Records
PUNISHMENT: Criminalizes forgery or misrepresentation of electronic records.
FAMOUS CASES: Up to 3 years imprisonment and/or fine.

DESCRIPTION: Breach of Confidentiality and Privacy
PUNISHMENT: Addresses unauthorized disclosure of confidential information by individuals in positions of trust.
FAMOUS CASES: Up to 2 years imprisonment and/or ₹1 lakh fine.

DESCRIPTION: Intermediary Liability for Offensive Content
PUNISHMENT: Holds intermediaries responsible for not acting promptly in removing illegal content.
FAMOUS CASES: Penalties for non-compliance.

DESCRIPTION: Penalty for Misuse of Digital Signature
PUNISHMENT: Penalizes forging or misusing digital signatures for fraudulent activities.
FAMOUS CASES: Up to 2 years imprisonment and/or fine.

DESCRIPTION: Offenses Committed Outside India
PUNISHMENT: Extends Indian laws to offenses committed abroad if they impact Indian citizens or entities.
FAMOUS CASES: Punishment depends on the offense committed.

DESCRIPTION: Offenses by Companies
PUNISHMENT: Holds companies liable for cyber offenses committed under the IT Act.
FAMOUS CASES: Companies face fines; responsible individuals may face personal liability.

DESCRIPTION: Cognizance of Offenses
PUNISHMENT: Empowers courts to take cognizance of offenses under the IT Act.

DESCRIPTION: Power of Police to Investigate Cybercrimes
PUNISHMENT: Grants police the authority to investigate offenses under the IT Act.

DESCRIPTION: Immunity for Intermediaries
PUNISHMENT: Provides immunity to intermediaries from legal liability if they act in good faith to prevent illegal activities.

DESCRIPTION: Power to Issue Directions
PUNISHMENT: Gives the Central Government authority to issue directions to intermediaries for preserving electronic records and providing information for investigations.
FAMOUS CASES: No direct penalties, but mandates compliance.

DESCRIPTION: Power to Make Rules
PUNISHMENT: Grants the Central Government the authority to formulate rules related to cybersecurity, privacy, data protection, and digital regulations.
FAMOUS CASES: No direct penalties; non-compliance can lead to consequences under other sections.

DESCRIPTION: Power to Make Rules for Electronic Signatures
PUNISHMENT: Authorizes the government to create rules for electronic signatures to ensure standardization and security in digital transactions.
FAMOUS CASES: No direct penalties, but ensures electronic signatures are legally recognized.

DESCRIPTION: Offenses by Companies
PUNISHMENT: Holds companies and responsible officers liable for offenses under the IT Act, including cybercrimes and data breaches.
FAMOUS CASES: Companies and officers may face fines, imprisonment, or both, depending on the offense.

DESCRIPTION: Offenses by Government Departments
PUNISHMENT: Ensures government departments and public sector entities are accountable for cybersecurity negligence and digital violations.
FAMOUS CASES: Imprisonment and fines for responsible officials.

DESCRIPTION: Penalty for Sending Offensive Messages
PUNISHMENT: Addresses sending offensive, threatening, or harassing messages via electronic communication services.
FAMOUS CASES: Imprisonment up to 3 years and/or fine up to ₹5 lakh.

DESCRIPTION: Penalty for Sending Offensive Messages with Criminal Intent
PUNISHMENT: Targets messages sent with intent to commit a crime, such as threats, fraud, or cyber harassment.
FAMOUS CASES: Imprisonment up to 5 years and/or fine up to ₹10 lakh.

DESCRIPTION: Penalty for Sending Offensive Messages with Intent to Cause Fear
PUNISHMENT: Covers cases where messages are sent to intimidate, extort, or create panic.
FAMOUS CASES: Imprisonment up to 5 years and/or fine up to ₹10 lakh.

DESCRIPTION: Penalty for Sending Offensive Messages with Intent to Harass
PUNISHMENT: Addresses cyberstalking and persistent online harassment.
FAMOUS CASES: Imprisonment up to 5 years and/or fine up to ₹10 lakh.

DESCRIPTION: Penalty for False Representation of the Origin of Electronic Messages
PUNISHMENT: Covers offenses like phishing and email fraud where the sender impersonates another entity.
FAMOUS CASES: Imprisonment up to 3 years and/or fine up to ₹5 lakh.

DESCRIPTION: Power to Give Directions to Intermediaries
PUNISHMENT: Allows the government to direct intermediaries to block or remove illegal/offensive content.
FAMOUS CASES: No direct penalties; intermediaries must comply with government orders.

DESCRIPTION: Power to Search and Seize
PUNISHMENT: Grants law enforcement the authority to search and seize electronic records for cybercrime investigations.
FAMOUS CASES: Legal enforcement power to aid in investigations.

DESCRIPTION: Power to Add New Provisions
PUNISHMENT: Allows the government to add new provisions to the IT Act to address evolving technological challenges.
FAMOUS CASES: No direct penalties, but expands regulatory scope.

DESCRIPTION: Power to Notify Offenses
PUNISHMENT: Enables the government to officially notify which offenses fall under legal action.
FAMOUS CASES: No direct penalties, but helps in legal enforcement.

DESCRIPTION: Power to Prescribe Forms
PUNISHMENT: Authorizes the government to prescribe forms for legal filings under the IT Act.
FAMOUS CASES: No direct penalties; facilitates legal compliance.
